body_html:
@drpngx
I fully understand that right now you can't pass a tensor.

What do you mean as an input?
If you mean just a const number, than sampling losses have a very narrow application.
If I understand correctly, in TF I can either pass a tensor or a numeric value (which is a const in itself in the context of a static graph).

Documentation:
num_true: Number of true labels per context.
and
num_true: An int. The number of target classes per training example.

Also, If I understand correctly it is the amount of true labels per each example, isn't it?
E.g. if a picture has ['dog', 'car', 'panda'] true labels, while there are 1000 possible classes, than num_true=3 and num_classes=1000.

If yes, then what exactly needs to be done for it to support a variable sizenum_true?
E.g. if I have images with different amount of num_true per example.

Also, If I understand correctly it is the amount of true labels per each example, isn't it?

If yes, then what exactly needs to be done for it to support a variable sizenum_true?
E.g. if I have images with different amount of num_true per example.
body:
@drpngx 
I fully understand that right now you can't pass a tensor.

What do you mean as an input?
If you mean just a const number, than sampling losses have a very narrow application.
If I understand correctly, in TF I can either pass a tensor or a numeric value (which is a const in itself in the context of a static graph).

Documentation:
`num_true: Number of true labels per context.` 
and
`num_true: An int. The number of target classes per training example.`

Also, If I understand correctly it is the amount of true labels per each example, isn't it? 
E.g. if a picture has ['dog', 'car', 'panda'] true labels, while there are 1000 possible classes, than `num_true=3` and `num_classes=1000`.

If yes, then what exactly needs to be done for it to support a variable size`num_true`?
E.g. if I have images with different amount of `num_true` per example.
